results.title: Manuel Vargas, Eurocentrism and the Philosophy of Liberation
results.snippet: Manuel Vargas · APA Newsletter ... counsel that various forms of liberation in at least the Americas requires that we should fight Eurocentrism and resist the ontology and conceptual framework of Europe....
extra_snippets: Manuel Vargas · APA Newsletter on Hispanic/Latino Issues 4 (2):8-17 (2005) Copy BIBTEX · Proponents of the philosophy of liberation generally counsel that various forms of liberation in at least the Americas requires that we should fight Eurocentrism and resist the ontology and conceptual framework of Europe.

Manuel Vargas · University of California, San Diego · Latin American Political Philosophy in Philosophy of the Americas · Latin American Philosophy Eurocentrism Philosophy of Liberation Dussel · No versions found · Upload a copy of this work Papers currently archived: 114,005 ·

Proponents of the philosophy of liberation generally counsel that various forms of liberation in at least the Americas requires that we should fight Eurocentrism and resist the ontology and conceptual framework of Europe. However, most of the work done in this tradition relies heavily on the terminology and theoretical apparatus of various strands of European philosophy.

The apparent disconnect between the aims and methods (or if you like, the theory and practice) has given rise to a criticism I call The Eurocentrism Problem. I argue that the Eurocentrism Problem has not received an adequate reply, and that it reflects a number of underlying flaws in the philosophical program of the philosophy of liberation.

results.title: Manuel Vargas, Lessons from the Philosophy of Race in Mexico
results.snippet: Eurocentrism and the Philosophy of Liberation.Manuel Vargas - 2005 - APA Newsletter on Hispanic/Latino Issues 4 (2):8-17.
extra_snippets: The precise conceptions of race de­ployed by Mexican philosophers in the first half of the twentieth century have often been poorly understood. Consequently, the specifi­cally racial components in their work have been frequently dismissed on the grounds that they were unscientific, irresponsible, and/or sloppy.

results.title: Linda Martín Alcoff & Eduardo Mendieta (eds.), Thinking From the Underside of History: Enrique Dussel's Philosophy of Liberation
results.snippet: Eurocentrism and the Philosophy of Liberation.Manuel Vargas - 2005 - APA Newsletter on Hispanic/Latino Issues 4 (2):8-17.
extra_snippets: Enrique Dussel's writings span the theology of liberation, critiques of discourse ethics, evaluations of Marx, Levinas, Habermas, and others, but most importantly, the development of a philosophy written from the underside of Eurocentric modernist teleologies, an ethics of the impoverished, and the articulation of a unique Latin American theoretical perspective.

results.title: Manuel Vargas, The Philosophy of Accidentality
results.snippet: In mid-twentieth-century Mexican philosophy, there was a peculiar nationalist existentialist project focused on the cultural conditions of agency. This article revisits some of those ideas, including the idea that there is ...
extra_snippets: In mid-twentieth-century Mexican philosophy, there was a peculiar nationalist existentialist project focused on the cultural conditions of agency. This article revisits some of those ideas, including the idea that there is an important but underappreciated experience of one's relationship to norms and social meanings.

extra_snippets: This is an essay on philosophical methodology, the disciplinary prejudices of the Anglophone philosophical world, and how these things interact with some aspects of the content and form of Latin American philosophy to preclude the latter's integration with mainstream Anglophone philosophical work.
